text: TITLE: What"healthy" food is actually way more unhealthy than most people think? POST: Incoming comments of things that are nutritious but people don't consider healthy because they're high in calories AND other random shit they read on a blog who's ultimate goal is to convince them to spend money on something at some point. Olive oil is healthy even though it has calories and fruit is healthy even though it has carbs. Dairy and red meat are fine - people have been consuming them for centuries and they did shit like building pyramids using just their hands. You don't need to live off of bland chicken breasts, broccoli, and scrambled eggs to be healthy. Also people need to learn the difference between added sugar and natural sugar. The sugar in fruit is not the same sugar in candy bars. I think one of the biggest reasons for the obesity epidemic in America is the over-complication of nutrition. A new food is"unhealthy" every week.

prediction.TITLE: What\"healthy\" food is actually:
Fallacy type(s): fallacy of division and appeal to worse problems. 
    
    
    Explanation: The argument claims that many healthy foods are unhealthy, which is not necessarily true. It also suggests that people should not eat these foods because they are unhealthy, which is a slippery slope fallacy. This argument appeals to worse problems by suggesting that the potential consequences of eating unhealthy foods are severe, which is not supported by scientific evidence. The argument also uses the fallacy of division by assuming that all parts of an argument must support each other, which is not the case in this situation.
prediction.Incoming comments of things that are nut: Fallacy type(s): appeal to worse problems, slippery slope. Explanation: The argument implies that the reason why nutritious foods are not considered healthy is because they are high in calories and people read about them on a blog that wants to sell something. This oversimplifies the issue of nutrition and creates a false dilemma by suggesting that there are only two options: unhealthy or expensive. Additionally, the argument suggests that since there are many other factors that can affect health besides calories, the problem is likely more complex than what is being suggested. This is an example of a slippery slope fallacy because it assumes that one thing (high calorie foods) leads to another (unhealthy foods are all high calorie), which is not necessarily true.
prediction.Olive oil is healthy even though it has: False analogy. The argument compares olive oil and fruit based on the premise that they are both healthy, which is true, but then asserts that they are both high in calories, which is not necessarily true. This is a false analogy because there is no logical connection between being healthy and having calories.

text:
TITLE: In mid-December, a model from the CA government predicted 75K COVID hospitalizations by mid-January, steep growth from the 16K then hospitalized. Yesterday, CA had less than 21K COVID hospitalizations.
POST: In all honesty have we seen one single Covid related model turn out to be correct or even close in the past 10 months?
POST: Every one I remember seeing has proven itself to be between 50% and 90% overstated. Our death counts ended up being 10% of what the models were forecasting. One of the cities here went from three overflow hospitals to finding locations for one back in April, then only building a permanent one which has never been staffed. They claim they don't have the personnel to staff them....despite the state's NG being given authorization from our governor to send its stock of nurses and doctors to do it.
